metadata.description: Comprehensive procedural guide for foreign students and workers in France

erasmus.name: Erasmus+ Exchange Students
erasmus.description: EU exchange program students spending 1-2 semesters in France

documents.name: European Health Insurance Card (EHIC)
documents.description: Free card providing access to state healthcare during temporary stay in EU countries
documents.howToObtain: Request from your national health insurance provider before departure
tips: Apply at least 1 month before departure
Take photos of both sides of the card
EHIC does not cover private healthcare or repatriation

documents.name: Learning Agreement
documents.description: Official document listing courses to be taken abroad, signed by home and host universities
documents.howToObtain: Coordinate with Erasmus coordinator at home university
tips: Ensure ECTS credits will be recognized
Can be modified within first month of arrival
Keep digital and physical copies

documents.name: Erasmus+ Grant Agreement
documents.description: Contract with home university specifying grant amount and conditions
documents.howToObtain: Sign with home university's international office

grantAmounts.group1: 350-500€/month (Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Ireland, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Norway, Sweden)
grantAmounts.group2: 300-450€/month (Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, France, Germany, Greece, Italy, Malta, Netherlands, Portugal, Spain)

tips: Grant is paid in installments
Keep all receipts for potential audits
Additional grants available for students with disabilities

documents.name: Valid Passport or National ID Card
documents.description: EU citizens can use national ID card; non-EU Erasmus students need valid passport
documents.validity: Must be valid for entire stay + 3 months
tips: Check expiry date before departure
Make copies stored separately from original

documents.name: Proof of Accommodation
documents.description: Confirmation of housing arrangement in France
tips: Needed for various administrative procedures
Address will be used for official correspondence

documents.name: Birth Certificate (with Apostille)
documents.description: Official birth certificate, apostilled or legalized depending on home country
documents.requiredFor: Opening bank accounts, some administrative procedures
documents.howToObtain: Request from civil registry in home country, then apostille at competent authority
tips: Hague Convention countries: apostille sufficient
Non-Hague countries: full legalization required
Some banks accept without translation

preparation.name: Apply for CROUS Housing
preparation.deadline: May-June for September arrival, November for January arrival
preparation.cost: 200-600€/month depending on city and room type
tips: Apply early - places are limited
Île-de-France is most competitive
Alternative: private housing via Studapart, Lokaviz

preparation.name: Open a French Bank Account (Online Pre-Application)
preparation.description: Some banks allow starting the process online before arrival

options.name: Boursorama Banque
options.requirements: French address, ID, proof of income/grant

tips: Neo-banks easier to open but may lack French RIB initially
Traditional banks often require appointment in person

preparation.name: Arrange Travel Insurance
preparation.description: Supplementary travel insurance recommended in addition to EHIC
tips: Check if home university provides coverage
Some credit cards include travel insurance

preparation.name: Register with Host University
preparation.description: Complete online pre-registration with French host institution
preparation.deadline: Varies by university - typically 2-3 months before semester
tips: Check specific requirements on host university website
Contact international office if no response within 2 weeks

preparation.name: Learn Basic French
preparation.description: Even in English-taught programs, basic French improves daily life significantly
tips: Focus on practical vocabulary: housing, food, transport
Many universities offer free French courses for exchange students

administrative.name: University Enrollment (Inscription Administrative)
administrative.description: Final registration at host university upon arrival
administrative.when: First week of arrival, during orientation
administrative.where: Host university's Scolarité or International Office
administrative.cost: Usually free for Erasmus (CVEC may be waived)
tips: Student card needed for library, restaurants, discounts
Check if CVEC (92€ contribution) is waived for Erasmus

administrative.name: Obtain Certificate of Arrival
administrative.description: Document proving your arrival date, required for Erasmus grant
administrative.purpose: Send to home university to trigger grant payment
tips: Get it signed and stamped
Keep copy for your records
You'll need another certificate when leaving

administrative.name: Sécurité Sociale Affiliation
administrative.description: French social security registration for healthcare coverage
tips: EU students: EHIC covers you initially
French Sécu allows additional reimbursements
Carte Vitale takes time - use attestation in meantime

administrative.name: Attend Orientation Week
administrative.description: Integration events organized by university and ESN
administrative.when: Week before or first week of classes
tips: Best way to meet other international students
Get ESN card for discounts (10€)
Don't miss welcome events!

housing.name: CROUS Residences
tips: Apply early via trouverunlogement.lescrous.fr
Eligible for CAF housing aid

housing.name: Private Student Residences
tips: More expensive but higher quality
Easier rental process for foreigners
Still eligible for CAF

housing.name: Private Rental Platforms
housing.description: Find apartments and rooms from private landlords

platforms.name: Leboncoin
platforms.description: General classifieds, good deals but beware scams

platforms.name: PAP (Particulier à Particulier)
platforms.description: Direct from owners, no agency fees

housing.scamWarning: NEVER pay before visiting. NEVER wire money abroad. Meet landlord in person.
tips: Use university housing services for verified listings
Ask for video call tour if arriving from abroad

housing.name: Colocation (Flatsharing)
housing.description: Sharing an apartment with other students

platforms.name: La Carte des Colocs
platforms.description: Most popular colocation site in France

tips: Great for meeting locals and improving French
Clarify bills, cleaning, guests rules upfront

housing.name: Visale Guarantee
housing.description: Free government guarantee replacing traditional guarantor
housing.coverage: Up to 36 months of unpaid rent
tips: Apply BEFORE signing lease
Some landlords don't know Visale - explain it's from Action Logement
Alternative: GarantMe (paid service)

housing.name: CAF Housing Aid Application
housing.eligibility: All students with legal rental contract
howToApply: Wait until you have signed lease
Upload: ID, lease, RIB, attestation de loyer
tips: Aid starts from application month, not retroactive
Apply immediately after moving in

health.name: Find a General Practitioner (Médecin Traitant)
health.description: Register with a GP for better reimbursements
howToFind: Doctolib app/website - filter by 'accepts new patients'
health.cost: 25€ standard consultation (70% reimbursed with Carte Vitale)
tips: Can declare médecin traitant later once you have Carte Vitale

health.name: Complementary Health Insurance (Mutuelle)
health.description: Optional additional coverage on top of Sécurité Sociale
health.whyNeeded: French Sécu only covers 70% of costs
tips: Low-income students may qualify for CSS (Complémentaire Santé Solidaire) - free
Check if home country insurance already provides coverage

health.name: University Health Services (SUMPPS/SSU)
tips: Great first point of contact
Can help navigate French health system

overview.description: Opening a French bank account is essential for receiving grants, paying rent, and daily expenses

traditionalBanks.name: BNP Paribas
tips: Go to a branch near universities - staff used to foreign students
Ask about Esprit Libre Découverte for first year free

traditionalBanks.name: Société Générale

traditionalBanks.name: Crédit Agricole
tips: Good option if studying outside major cities
Ask about EKO sub-brand (digital, cheaper)

traditionalBanks.name: LCL (Le Crédit Lyonnais)

neoBanks.name: N26

neoBanks.internationalTransfers: Free SEPA, Wise integration for others

neoBanks.name: Revolut
cons: Lithuanian IBAN - CAF usually doesn't accept
tips: Great for traveling and currency exchange

neoBanks.name: Boursorama Banque
pros: Fully accepted for CAF, rent, etc.

neoBanks.name: Fortuneo
tips: Alternative to Boursorama
Check welcome bonuses

neoBanks.name: Hello bank!
tips: Good middle ground between traditional and neo-bank
Can use BNP branches if needed

studentSpecificOptions.name: Nickel
pros: Open in 5 minutes at any tabac
tips: Perfect emergency option if other banks refuse
Can open day of arrival
5,500 tobacco shops in France

moneyTransfers.name: Wise (ex-TransferWise)
tips: Much cheaper than bank transfers
Useful for receiving money from family
Can link to N26/Revolut

moneyTransfers.name: Western Union
tips: Good for emergencies when you need cash
Many pickup points in France
Open N26/Revolut immediately upon arrival while waiting for French bank
Apply for Boursorama once you have proof of address
Traditional banks good for building relationship (loans later)
Always keep some cash for emergencies (card machines fail)
Never give card PIN or online banking codes to anyone
Set up transaction alerts on all accounts

recommendedStrategy.step1: Before arrival: Open N26 or Revolut with EU ID
recommendedStrategy.step2: Week 1: Open Nickel at tabac if urgent French IBAN needed
recommendedStrategy.step3: Week 2-3: Apply at traditional bank near university OR Boursorama online
recommendedStrategy.step4: Keep neo-bank for daily spending, French bank for official things (CAF, rent)

studentRestaurants.name: CROUS Restaurant Universitaire (RU)

studentRestaurants.name: CROUS Cafétérias

foodBanks.name: Secours Populaire
